comments.comment: Use of the blockchain technology as a consensus. Ethereum is good in the way that it allows to create parallel private/consensus/public blockchains based on ethereum without the need to get the hand dirty (trust in ethereum foundation to maintain the blockchain technology and POW/POS/POA).
We need to however to create a decentralized storage service that would work with ethereum. For example unique links to data (link + key + timestamp?).
Updated the architecture
The chosen consensus is Ethereum. A new architecture with an ethereum private blockchain has been made.
blockchain technology could become heavy. as a solution we can generate a new genesis block and distribute it to clients.

maidsafe (small group consensus) includes the decentralized storage. But it is not open to developers yet. Plus the hype is low currently and compared to Ethereum trending (google), maidsafe doesn't even come close to the progression (close to nothing).
Alternative blockchains don't look as attractive as ethereum. Indeed, they are the only one giving a virtual machine to run code on the network (smart contracts).

Browser based blockchain doesn't exist. Browser solutions to mine exist however., a combination of JS, HTML5, WebGL. Could be interesting to investigate, but i don't think I will have time during this project timing (TB).

NodeJS+NPM are at start designed to work on a server. However, with the browserify technology, nodejs code can be bundle to run in the browser, but it's not an universal or magic technic, it could need some work is the npm package for example isn't designed to work with browserify right out of the box. EthereumJS has already modules compatible with Broswerify.

The project planning has been made for 8 weeks. It was devised into 8 sprints starting and ending at each week Wednesday. We will be using the software called Vivifyscrum; the​ school will be paying the 10$ fee for each month of the project.
The student will be at Neuchatel, at least for the 4-5 first weeks, he will take a work room on the campus.
Specifications of the project have been validated during this 1st sprint. We are still waiting for​ a meeting with the Expert.

items.name: Research IDE & workspace for web dev
items.description: Using tools? Or just text editor..?

comments.comment: Okay, so NodeJS and NPM is for serverside... Need to understand if browserify could help to move to the client side only.
Wakanda is working only with rest services (server).. plus it's based on widgets mostly.
We can generate a desktop app with nodejs. It's sort of a chrome browser, without a toolbar. (we could add tool bar if wished). Node Webkit
options could be to bundle nodejs

https://github.com/jaredallard/nexe
http://electron.atom.io
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify
http://enclosejs.com

with the help of browserify, it should be possible to run nodeJS code right from the browser (double click on index.html).
However, not all npm packages are compatible right away... It could need some custom adjustments.
note that ethereumjsVM for example is compatible with browserify, and other ethereumjs parts too.

items.name: What is trust?
items.description: What is a digital trust? How to define it? State of art.

comments.comment: http://dupress.com/articles/blockchain-applications-and-trust-in-a-global-economy/
Way to be sure that the transactions are not malicious.​
That no one is trying to take advantage of the system.
the identity is taken care by Ethereum.
at this point of brainstorming, a certificate for a node (hardware) is not required. I don't see any use of it in our configuration.
indeed, on a security point of view, the hardware certification can be manipulated  with virtualization.

Plus on a point of view of features. I don't see how it could be useful. The user will have to protect his identity keys, but I don't see how a hardware certification layer could be helpful otherwise. Note that we want the user to be able to use its identity everywhere (whatever node).
The only feature I see is to ban a node from the network is used by terrorist identities for example. However, they could use virtualized nodes... so​ not useful.
http://geoffreywoo.com/the-blockchain-story
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EigenTrust
It could be interesting to keep track of the popular identities. call it PoP (proof of participation)
For example, if they submit community contracts, if their community contracts are accepted
If they participate to the data tribunal
Providing storage, gateways, PoW, PoS (called PoA proof of activity) are not considered as popularity
A solution to trust 3rd parties (storage + gateways) would be to go via community contracts (api to use the storage) to submit it to vote.

items.name: Objective: Have concept of the mesh-of-trust. How it works.

items.description: Each user has its own identity keys
Levels of trust (Certificates and Identity)Trust giving (Manual or Automatic)

comments.comment: a lot is already done with ethereum (blockchain)
table on git repo
Can also be called as Proof of Participation
Identities are signing contracts. If the contracts are used in overclouds, they earn notoriety​.
Identities participating in the data tribunal earn notoriety if they are part of the majority.
Identities lose notoriety (negative points are possible) if they are too often in the minority of the data tribunal.
Identities lose notoriety if they are judged as negative to the network (storage, gateway)
